G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 28A, 31, a.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, 31, and 31A, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a Complaint for Modification of an existing Probate and Family Court custody and parenting-time order concerning a minor child domiciled in the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 28A, 31, and 31A, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, as this is a Complaint for Modification of an existing Probate and Family Court custody and parenting-time order concerning a minor child domiciled in the Commonwealth.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, this Court may modify a judgment as to custody or parenting time “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require” upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is in the child’s best interests. See also Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, this Court may modify a judgment as to custody or parenting time “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require” upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is in the child’s best interests. See also Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.support_reasoning: This opinion discusses modification in the context of (1) removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and (2) child support modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28, but not custody or parenting time under § 28. The only reference to § 28 concerns the statutory standard for modifying child support orders, not custody or parenting time, and the case does not articulate the “material and substantial change in circumstances” standard for custody/parenting-time modification. Thus, Murray v. Super does not support the specific proposition for which it is cited here.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 2011, c. 93, § 37, provides that a child support order shall be modified ‘if there is an inconsistency between the amount of the existing order and the amount that would result from application of the child support guidelines.’ Although the father alleged that there had been a material change of circumstances, the judge here was correct to apply those guidelines to the parties’ updated financial circumstances.”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, this Court may modify a judgment as to custody or parenting time “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require” upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and that modification is in the child’s best interests. See also Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly quotes G.L. c. 208, § 28’s standard for modifying a custody judgment, stating that modification requires a finding of a “material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties” and that the modification “is necessary in the best interests of the child.” Although the statute’s broader phrasing (“as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require”) is not quoted verbatim, the case clearly affirms the two‑part material-change and best‑interests test that the proposition describes, and applies it to custody/parenting determinations.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that in making custody and parenting-time determinations, “the rights of the parents shall, in the absence of misconduct, be held to be equal, and the happiness and welfare of the children shall determine their custody.” G.L. c. 208, § 31; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that in making custody and parenting-time determinations, “the rights of the parents shall, in the absence of misconduct, be held to be equal, and the happiness and welfare of the children shall determine their custody.” G.L. c. 208, § 31; Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The Yannas opinion discusses G.L. c. 208, § 31, but only to reject a claimed presumption favoring joint physical custody and to define joint legal custody. It does not set out or apply any rule that, in the absence of misconduct, the rights of the parents are equal and that the children’s happiness and welfare determine custody. That quoted language comes from the statute, not from Yannas, and the case is focused on best‑interests and removal standards rather than announcing the statutory equal‑rights principle cited in the proposition.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The husband argues that there should be a presumption in favor of joint custody of minor children and that the trial judge failed to recognize that presumption. There is no such presumption in the broad terms asserted. The judge did award joint or shared legal custody, which G. L. c. 208, § 31 (1984 ed.), defines as ‘a continued mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in decisions regarding the child’s welfare….’ … We reject the husband’s assertion that the law of the Commonwealth favors or should presumptively favor joint physical custody. Nothing in G. L. c. 208, § 31, supports such a view.”

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293\u20.proposition: To warrant modification of a custody or parenting-time judgment, the moving party must show (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests. See Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293–294 (2009); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546–548 (2010); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 150–151 (2015).
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293\u20.support_reasoning: Pierce is an alimony-modification case, not a custody or parenting-time case. The opinion articulates the standard for modifying alimony or child support (“material change of circumstances”), but it does not discuss custody, parenting time, or the additional requirement that a modification be in the child’s best interests. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific custody/parenting-time modification proposition cited, even though it supports a parallel standard in the alimony context.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293\u20.relevant_excerpt: “‘To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’ Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981).”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.proposition: To warrant modification of a custody or parenting-time judgment, the moving party must show (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests. See Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293–294 (2009); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546–548 (2010); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 150–151 (2015).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurrence focused on relocation in a paternity context and on statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 209C; it does not set out the general standard for modification of a custody or parenting-time judgment. The text provided does not discuss the two-prong ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ plus ‘best interests of the child’ test, nor does it purport to articulate a general modification standard. If the majority opinion elsewhere states that standard, it is not reflected in the excerpt given here.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546\u2.relevant_excerpt: "After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate."

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 150–151 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.proposition: To warrant modification of a custody or parenting-time judgment, the moving party must show (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests. See Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286, 293–294 (2009); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540, 546–548 (2010); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 150–151 (2015).
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.support_reasoning: This opinion involves (1) a removal request governed by the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test and G. L. c. 208, § 30, and (2) a child support modification governed by G. L. c. 208, § 28 and the Child Support Guidelines. It does not articulate or apply the general two‑prong standard for modification of custody or parenting-time judgments (material and substantial change plus best interests) referenced in Pierce and Smith. The quoted pages focus on removal and child support standards, so using Murray as authority for the broad custody/parenting-time modification standard is not accurate.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.relevant_excerpt: “The mother, Dawn Michelle Murray, appeals from a judgment of the Probate and Family Court dismissing her complaint for modification, which sought to remove the minor children of the marriage to the State of California. Where the parent seeking to move has primary physical custody of the children, the standard governing removal of the minor children from the Commonwealth requires a determination whether there is a real advantage to the custodial parent and consideration of the best interests of the children and the interests of both parents. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710-711 (1985).”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: In assessing best interests, the Court considers, among other factors, the child’s age and developmental needs, the child’s relationship with each parent, the stability and suitability of each parent’s home, and the child’s schooling and routines. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the ‘best interests of the child’ standard generally and emphasizes stability, continuity, primary caregiver status, parental relationships, and work/daycare schedules. However, it does not set out or synthesize a multi-factor list including the child’s age, developmental needs, and schooling/routines in the way the proposition states. While the judge’s findings mention weekday vs. weekend time and school-year vs. summer arrangements, the case is focused on statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) and the concept of stability, rather than articulating the broader factor set claimed in the proposition.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge… However, we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ … It is apparent that the judge’s final judgment was intended to accomplish the objective of preserving ‘to the extent possible’ the relationship between the child and her parents at the time of his decision.”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: In assessing best interests, the Court considers, among other factors, the child’s age and developmental needs, the child’s relationship with each parent, the stability and suitability of each parent’s home, and the child’s schooling and routines. See G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: Vilakazi discusses that custody determinations are governed by the overarching principle of the welfare of the child and the judge’s discretion, but it does not articulate or analyze specific best-interest factors such as age and developmental needs, relationships with each parent, home stability, or schooling and routines. The opinion affirms the decree based on deference to the probate judge’s findings and cites earlier cases for the general ‘welfare of the child’ standard, without setting out the detailed multifactor framework described in the proposition. Thus, it does not provide authority for that specific, factor-based best-interests test.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ … ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”}

Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260.raw_text: Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260, 267–268 (1990)
Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260.proposition: A substantial improvement or change in a parent’s housing and living arrangements may constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of parenting time. See Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260, 267–268 (1990) (changed conditions and improved environment can warrant modification); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 150–151.
Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260.support_reasoning: The opinion is a care-and-protection case about adjudicating parental unfitness and committing children to DSS custody, not a modification of parenting time or custody based on changed circumstances. The cited pages discuss evidentiary issues and the sufficiency of evidence for removal, and the only reference to possible future change is a general statement that if the parents can later organize a stable home, reunification remains the goal. The court does not hold or suggest that improved housing or living arrangements, as such, constitute a material and substantial change justifying modification of parenting time.
Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260.relevant_excerpt: “At that, the opportunity of the parents to regain custody has not been cut off. Should they be able to organize a home life sufficiently stable to meet the needs of their children, reunification remains the goal of the judge’s order. See G. L. c. 119, §§ 1, 26(2)(iii). In the meantime, the intervention of the court was proper.”

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 15.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 150–151
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 15.proposition: A substantial improvement or change in a parent’s housing and living arrangements may constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of parenting time. See Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260, 267–268 (1990) (changed conditions and improved environment can warrant modification); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 150–151.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: The Court also recognizes the importance of a stable, developmentally appropriate parenting schedule and maintaining and strengthening the relationship between a child and both parents, where consistent with the child’s welfare. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); G.L. c. 208, § 31.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Vaughn focuses on the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its impact on the child when making custody and shared custody determinations. While it discusses the child’s bond with the father and his functioning at school, the case does not articulate a general principle about the importance of a stable, developmentally appropriate parenting schedule or affirmatively maintaining and strengthening the relationship with both parents. Its core legal holding is about mandatory consideration and findings regarding domestic violence, not about co-parenting or schedules between both parents.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The Court also recognizes the importance of a stable, developmentally appropriate parenting schedule and maintaining and strengthening the relationship between a child and both parents, where consistent with the child’s welfare. See Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); G.L. c. 208, § 31.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion does not use the exact phrase "stable, developmentally appropriate parenting schedule," but its relocation analysis repeatedly emphasizes maintaining the child’s relationship with both parents and protecting his emotional, physical, and developmental needs. The court notes the benefit of Caleb’s "frequent, continuing and equal interaction" with both parents and remands for a visitation schedule that preserves ongoing meaningful contact, reflecting a concern with a stable, developmentally appropriate arrangement and strengthening relationships with both parents consistent with the child’s welfare.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: "Caleb was found to be a ‘physically and emotionally healthy’ boy whose ‘frequent, continuing and equal interaction . . . with each parent is most beneficial to him.’ ‘Both parents serve as equally important guides for this child’s continued healthy development.’ ‘The Court finds the minor child’s life is enriched by each parent’s equal participation in his upbringing.’ ... There is nothing in the evidence to suggest that a relocation to Providence, fifty-five miles from Northborough, would preclude the father ... from having contact with Caleb in a manner significantly different from that provided by the original divorce judgment."

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: The changes in the minor child’s age and developmental stage, his full‑time school schedule, the negative impact of frequent short visits on school nights, Father’s significantly improved housing, and the child’s desire for overnights with Father collectively constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the 2019 Order within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and applicable case law, including Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); and Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: Pierce is an alimony‑modification case, not a custody or parenting‑time case, and it does not involve G.L. c. 208, § 28 or analysis of what constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances regarding a child’s schedule, developmental stage, housing, or preferences. Its discussion of “material change of circumstances” is limited to the alimony context under §§ 34 and 37. Using Pierce to support that specific parenting‑time modification proposition misstates the scope and subject of the decision.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “‘To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’ Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981). … A court must consider these same factors in determining whether the amount of alimony should be modified based on a change of circumstances following entry of an earlier judgment for alimony. See G. L. c. 208, § 37 …”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842\u20138.proposition: The requested modification is consistent with the statutory directive that the Court “shall consider the welfare of the children as paramount,” see G.L. c. 208, § 31; Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842–843, and is tailored to address the specific material changes in circumstances described above.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28 and 31.proposition: Under the totality of the circumstances, and in light of the legal standards set out in G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31 and the cases including Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); and Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260 (1990), the existing 2019 Order should be modified.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Under the totality of the circumstances, and in light of the legal standards set out in G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31 and the cases including Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); and Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260 (1990), the existing 2019 Order should be modified.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: This concurring opinion in Smith v. McDonald concerns statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 209C and the limits on a judge’s authority to order a relocating, sole-legal parent to return to Massachusetts before paternity is established. It does reference best‑interests and stability concepts (citing Custody of Kali), but it does not address modification of an existing custody/visitation order under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31, nor does it set out a totality‑of‑the‑circumstances standard for modifying a later order such as a 2019 order. Thus, it does not provide direct authority for the proposition that an existing 2019 order “should be modified” under those standards.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) (‘If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement…’).”

Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260.raw_text: Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260 (1990)
Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260.proposition: Under the totality of the circumstances, and in light of the legal standards set out in G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31 and the cases including Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015); and Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260 (1990), the existing 2019 Order should be modified.
Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260.support_reasoning: Custody of Michel is a care-and-protection case under G.L. c. 119 involving state removal of children from their parents, not a modification of an existing custody order between parents under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 31. The opinion does not discuss the domestic relations custody-modification standards or a “totality of the circumstances” analysis for changing an existing c. 208 order. Consequently, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a 2019 c. 208 custody order should be modified under those standards.
Custody of Michel, 28 Mass. App. Ct. 260.relevant_excerpt: “Parental fitness is tied to what lies in the best interests of the children… Temporary removal of a child from biological parents does not require that the child have suffered maltreatment… A judge sitting on this sort of case does not have to wait for disaster to happen. In determining parental fitness a judge may use past conduct to predict future ability and performance.” (28 Mass. App. Ct. at 269-270).
